<li>Using simple nonjudgmental statements to acknowledge loss: "I want you to know I'm thinking of you."</li>
<li>Referring to a loved one or object of loss by name (if acceptable in the client's culture).</li>
<li>Remembering words are not always necessary; a light touch on the elbow, shoulder, or hand or just being there indicates caring.</li>
<li>Respecting the client's unique process of grieving.</li>
<li>Respecting the client's personal beliefs.</li>
<li>Being honest, dependable, consistent, and worthy of the client's trust.</li>
</ul>
<p>A welcoming smile and eye contact from the client during intimate conversations usually indicate the nurse's trustworthiness, but the nurse must be aware that nonverbal behaviors may have different meanings or connotations in other cultures.</p>
<p>394</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260121-9f5e39cc.jpeg" alt="img-42.jpeg"></p>
<p>The nurse's tools</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nursing-interventions">NURSING INTERVENTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-interventions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Explore client's perception and meaning of his or her loss.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Allow adaptive denial.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Encourage or assist the client in reaching out for and accepting support.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Encourage client to examine patterns of coping in past and present situation of loss.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Encourage client to review personal strengths and personal power.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Encourage client to care for him or herself.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Offer client food without pressure to eat.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use effective communication:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Offer presence and give broad openings.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use open-ended questions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Encourage description.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Share observations.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use reflection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Seek validation of perceptions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Provide information.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Voice doubt.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use focusing.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Attempt to translate into feelings or verbalize the implied.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Establish rapport and maintain interpersonal skills such as</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Attentive presence.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Respect for client’s unique grieving process.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Respect for client’s personal beliefs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Being trustworthy: honest, dependable, consistent.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Periodic self-inventory of attitudes and issues related to loss.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="evaluation">Evaluation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#evaluation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Evaluation of progress depends on the goals established for the client. A review of the tasks and phases of grieving (discussed earlier in the chapter) can be useful in making a statement about the client’s status at any given moment. The nurse may say the client is still experiencing denial or outcry emotions or that the client is showing signs of reorganization, recovery, or healing.</p>
<p>Clients who are grieving need more than someone who is equipped with skills and basic knowledge; they need the support of someone they can trust with their emotions and thoughts. For clients to see nurses as trustworthy, nurses must be willing to examine their personal attitudes about loss and the grieving process.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-vignette-grief">CLINICAL VIGNETTE: Grief<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-vignette-grief" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>John Meyers is a 54-year-old man struggling with the recent unexpected death of his wife in an automobile accident. He has two grown children, aged 28 and 26, who have families of their own and live in another state. He has been increasingly withdrawn from friends and other family members, telling them “I’m OK. I just need to be alone.” He isn’t eating,</p>
<p>is losing weight, not sleeping well, and hasn't shaved or attended to his basic needs in a week or so. He mutters to himself, "This can't be happening. What am I going to do?" Finally, a coworker takes him to an urgent care clinic. The physician there recommends a short, inpatient hospitalization since John told him, "I can't go on" but doesn't elaborate on what he means.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nursing-care-plan-grieving">NURSING CARE PLAN: GRIEVING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-care-plan-grieving" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nursing-diagnosis">Nursing Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Grieving: A complex process in response to loss that includes all human dimensions as individuals, families, and communities integrate changes into daily life</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="assessment-data">ASSESSMENT DATA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment-data" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Actual or potential loss of health, abilities, or life</li>
<li>Denial of loss</li>
<li>Difficulty in accepting significant loss</li>
<li>Denial of feelings</li>
<li>Difficulty in expressing feelings</li>
<li>Fear of intensity of feelings</li>
<li>Expression of distress regarding potential loss</li>
<li>Anger, hostility, rage, or aggressive behavior</li>
<li>Guilt feelings</li>
<li>Crying</li>
<li>Anhedonia (inability to experience pleasure)</li>
<li>Ambivalent feelings toward the lost person or object</li>
<li>Suicidal ideas or feelings</li>
<li>Depressive behavior</li>
<li>Sorrow</li>
<li>Rumination</li>
<li>Resentment</li>
<li>Feelings of despair, hopelessness, disillusionment</li>
<li>Feelings of helplessness or powerlessness</li>
<li>Loss of interest in activities of daily living</li>
<li>Anxiety or fear</li>
</ul>
<p>397</p>
<ul>
<li>Agitation</li>
<li>Fatigue</li>
<li>Withdrawn behavior</li>
<li>Changes in eating habits</li>
<li>Sleep disturbances</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="expected-outcomes">EXPECTED OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#expected-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="immediate">Immediate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immediate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>The client will</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Be safe and free of self-inflicted harm throughout hospitalization.</li>
<li>Verbally identify the loss, potential loss, or illness within 24 to 48 hours.</li>
<li>Verbalize or demonstrate decreased suicidal, aggressive, depressive, or withdrawn behavior within 24 to 48 hours.</li>
<li>Express feelings verbally and nonverbally, for example, talk with staff about the grief situation for at least 30 minutes at least twice a day within 2 to 4 days.</li>
<li>Establish or maintain adequate nutrition, hydration, and elimination, for example, eat at least 30% of all meals with staff assistance within 2 to 4 days.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stabilization">Stabilization<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stabilization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>The client will</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Verbalize acceptance of the loss or illness.</li>
<li>Discuss loss or illness with significant others.</li>
<li>Verbalize knowledge of the grief process.</li>
<li>Establish or maintain an adequate balance of rest, sleep, and activity.</li>
<li>Verbalize changes in lifestyle and coping mechanisms incorporating the fact of the loss.</li>
<li>Demonstrate initial integration of the loss into his or her life, for example, verbalize realistic future plans integrating the loss.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="community">Community<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#community" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>The client will</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Demonstrate physical recuperation from the stress of loss and grieving.</li>
<li>Participate in continued therapy if indicated, for example, identify a therapist and make an initial appointment prior to discharge.</li>
<li>Progress through the grief process.</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>·Demonstrate reestablished relationships or social support in the community. IMPLEMENTATION</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Nursing Interventions</td><td>Rationale</td></tr><tr><td>Be alert to risk of suicidal behavior. Institute suicide precautions as needed.</td><td>Clients facing loss of health and functioning may be at increased risk for suicide.</td></tr><tr><td>Initially, assign the same staff members to the client. Gradually introduce new staff members.</td><td>The client's ability to relate to others may be impaired. Limiting the number of new contacts initially will promote familiarity and trust and decrease feelings of being overwhelmed.</td></tr><tr><td>Approach the client in a nonjudgmental way. Be sure to deal with your own feelings of discomfort, if any, related to the client's situation or grief.</td><td>The client may fear others' reactions to the illness or terminal situation. Being aware of and dealing with your own feelings will help prevent them from interfering in your work with the client.</td></tr><tr><td>Approach the client and initiate interactions; use silence and active listening to facilitate communication.</td><td>The client may fear rejection from others if he or she talks about the illness. Your presence indicates caring and acceptance.</td></tr><tr><td>As the client tolerates, encourage discussion of the client's illness or situation, first with staff members, then with the client's significant others and other clients. Be gentle in your approach to the client; talk about the situation in simple, matter-of-fact terms.*</td><td>Acknowledging the illness and loss is necessary to the grief process. Gentleness demonstrates regard for the client's feelings. Being matter-of-fact about the illness can help separate the illness itself from emotional issues.</td></tr><tr><td>Talk with the client in realistic terms concerning the loss; discuss concrete changes that have occurred or that the client must now make as a result of the loss.</td><td>Discussing the loss on this level may help make it more real for the client.</td></tr><tr><td>Encourage the client to express his or her feelings verbally and nonverbally in nondestructive ways.</td><td>Ventilation of feelings can help lessen feelings of despair and so forth and helps the client progress through the grief process.</td></tr><tr><td>Encourage the client to recall experiences and talk about the relationship with the lost person and so forth. Discuss changes in the client's feelings toward self, others, and the lost person.</td><td>Discussing the loss can help the client identify and express what the loss means to him or her and his or her feelings.</td></tr><tr><td>With the client, identify his or her strengths;</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th>resources; and sources of hope, pleasure, and support.</th><th>The client may feel so overwhelmed that he or she is unable to see anything positive.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Provide opportunities for the client to release tension, anger, and so forth through physical activity, and promote this as a healthy way of dealing with stress.</td><td>Physical activity provides a way to relieve tension in a healthy, nondestructive manner.</td></tr><tr><td>Point out to the client that a major aspect of loss is a real physical stress. Encourage good nutrition, hydration, rest, and daily physical exercise (such as walking, swimming, cycling).</td><td>The client may be unaware of the physical stress of the loss or may lack interest in basic needs. Physical exercise can relieve tension in a healthy manner.</td></tr><tr><td>Give the client honest praise for the things that he or she is able to do; acknowledge the client’s efforts in the context of the illness, impaired abilities, or dying.</td><td>The client will not benefit from dishonesty or flattery, but small accomplishments may indeed merit praise in the context of a major illness.</td></tr><tr><td>Assure the client that the illness is not a form of punishment and that he or she does not deserve to have the illness.</td><td>The client or others may feel that illness is a punishment or that the client is to blame.</td></tr><tr><td>Referral to the facility chaplain, clergy, or other spiritual resource person may be indicated.*</td><td>The client may be more comfortable discussing spiritual issues with an advisor who shares his or her belief system.</td></tr><tr><td>Point out to the client and his or her significant others that having a chronic or terminal illness and grieving are difficult tasks, and give the client positive feedback for his or her efforts.*</td><td>The client may not realize the difficulty of the work that he or she is doing to face and live with the illness.</td></tr><tr><td>Encourage the client to identify and maintain supportive relationships outside the hospital.*</td><td>The client may fear rejection from others in his or her life and may need encouragement to contact others.</td></tr><tr><td>Help the client identify resources for assistance in the community or via the internet. Referral to a social worker may be indicated.*</td><td>The client may need continued support after discharge. Social workers can help the client identify and contact resources. Many communities and organizations provide information, services, and support groups for clients who have chronic or terminal illnesses.</td></tr><tr><td>Encourage the client to continue therapy after discharge if indicated.*</td><td>Grieving and chronic or terminal illness may require long-term therapy.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>*Denotes collaborative interventions.</p>
<p>401</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="best-practice-grief-intervention-after-suicide">BEST PRACTICE: Grief Intervention after Suicide<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#best-practice-grief-intervention-after-suicide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Persons in grief after suicide of a loved one are at risk for complicated grief. These individuals need specific interventions dealing with death by suicide beyond traditional grief counseling.</p>
<p>The next step is screening all suicide survivors and referral to grief therapy particularly designed to deal with suicidal death. Early identification and participation in targeted grief therapy can be successful in avoiding or minimizing complicated grief.</p>
<p>Linde, K., Tremi, J., Steinig, J., Nagi, M., &amp; Kersting, A. (2017). Grief intervention for people bereaved by suicide: A systematic review. PloS One, 12(6), e0179496.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="self-awareness-issues">SELF-AWARENESS ISSUES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#self-awareness-issues" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="points-to-consider-when-working-with-clients-with-grief-and-loss">Points to Consider When Working with Clients with Grief and Loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#points-to-consider-when-working-with-clients-with-grief-and-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Taking a self-awareness inventory means periodic reflection on questions, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>What are the losses in my life, and how do they affect me?</li>
<li>Am I currently grieving for a significant loss? How does my loss affect my ability to be present to my client?</li>
<li>Who is there for me as I grieve?</li>
<li>How am I coping with my loss?</li>
<li>Is the pain of my personal grief spilling over as I listen and watch for cues of the client’s grieving?</li>
<li>Am I making assumptions about the client’s experience based on my own process?</li>
<li>Can I keep appropriate nurse-client boundaries as I attend to the client’s needs?</li>
<li>Do I have the strength to be present and facilitate the client’s grief?</li>
<li>What does my supervisor or a trusted colleague observe about my current</li>
</ul>
<p>ability to support a client in the grief process?</p>
<p>Ongoing self-examination is an effective method of keeping the therapeutic relationship goal-directed and acutely attentive to the client's needs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="critical-thinking-questions">CRITICAL THINKING QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#critical-thinking-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>What are some of the losses that a client might experience besides death of a loved one or life-threatening illness? Among clients in mental health, what are some of the common losses identified in their history?</li>
<li>Think about a significant loss in your own life. How did others respond to you? What was helpful? What do you take from that experience that will influence how you respond to others?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-points">KEY POINTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-points" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Grief refers to the subjective emotions and affect that are normal responses to the experience of loss.</li>
<li>Grieving is the process by which a person experiences grief.</li>
<li>Types of losses can be identified as unfulfilled or unmet human needs. Maslow's hierarchy of human needs is a useful model to understand loss as it relates to unfulfilled human needs.</li>
<li>Grief work is one of life's most difficult challenges. The challenge of integrating a loss requires all that the person can give of mind, body, and spirit.</li>
<li>Because the nurse constantly interacts with clients at various points on the health-illness continuum, he or she must understand loss and the process of grieving.</li>
<li>The process of grieving has been described by many theorists including Kübler-Ross, Bowlby, Engel, and Horowitz.</li>
<li>Dimensions of human response include cognitive, emotional, spiritual, behavioral, and physiologic. People may be experiencing more than one phase of the grieving process at a time.</li>
<li>Culturally bound reactions to loss are often lost in the acculturation to dominant societal norms. Both universal and culture-specific rituals</li>
</ul>
<p>402</p>
<p>facilitate grieving.</p>
<ul>
<li>Disenfranchised grief often involves deaths, mourners, or situations that are not socially supported or sanctioned, or carry a stigma for the mourners.</li>
<li>Complicated grieving is a response that lies outside the norm. The person may be void of emotion, grieve for a prolonged period, or express feelings that seem out of proportion.</li>
<li>Low self-esteem, distrust of others, a psychiatric disorder, previous suicide threats or attempts, and absent or unhelpful family members increase the risk of complicated grieving.</li>
<li>Situations considered risk factors for complicated grief in those already vulnerable include death of a spouse or child, a sudden unexpected death, and murder.</li>
<li>During assessment, the nurse observes and listens for cues in what the person thinks and feels and how he or she behaves, and then uses these relevant data to guide the client in the grieving process.</li>
<li>Crisis theory can be used to help the nurse working with a grieving client. Adequate perception, adequate support, and adequate coping are critical factors.</li>
<li>Effective communication skills are the key to successful assessment and interventions.</li>
<li>Interventions focused on the perception of loss include exploring the meaning of the loss and allowing adaptive denial, which is the process of gradually adjusting to the reality of a loss.</li>
<li>Being there to help the client while assisting him or her in seeking other sources of support is an essential intervention.</li>
<li>Encouraging the client to care for him or herself promotes adequate coping.</li>
<li>To earn the client's trust, the nurse must examine his or her own attitudes about loss and periodically take a self-awareness inventory.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f754c9e7">Unfolding Patient Stories: G.P. • Part 1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f754c9e7" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>G.P., 90 years old, was diagnosed 6 months ago with minor neurocognitive</p>
<p>403</p>
<p>disorder, Alzheimer type. He lives independently in an apartment within a retirement community. His wife of 65 years died 3 years ago. He was managing well until the recent loss of his 13-year-old dog. What responses and behaviors associated with bereavement should the nurse consider when assessing G.P.? How can his cognitive disorder complicate the process of grieving? How can the nurse guide his progression through grief and bereavement? G.P.'s story continues in Chapter 24.</p>
<p>Care for G.P. and other patients in a realistic virtual environment: vSim for Nursing (<a href="http://thepoint.lww.com/vSimMentalHealth" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://thepoint.lww.com/vSimMentalHealth</a>). Practice documenting these patients' care in DocuCare (thepoint.lww.com/DocuCareEHR).</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="additional-readings">ADDITIONAL READINGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-readings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>Chapter Study Guide</p>
<p>MULTIPLE CHOICE QUESTIONS</p>
<p>Select the best answer for each.</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Which of the following give cues to the nurse that a client may be grieving for a loss?
a. Sad affect, anger, anxiety, and sudden changes in mood
b. Thoughts, feelings, behavior, and physiologic complaints
c. Hallucinations, panic level of anxiety, and sense of impending doom
d. Complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and loss of appetite</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Situations that are considered risk factors for complicated grief are
a. inadequate support and old age.
b. childbirth, marriage, and divorce.
c. death of a spouse or child, death by suicide, and sudden and unexpected death.
d. inadequate perception of the grieving crisis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Physiologic responses of complicated grieving include
a. tearfulness when recalling significant memories of the lost one.
b. impaired appetite, weight loss, lack of energy, and palpitations.
c. depression, panic disorders, and chronic grief.
d. impaired immune system, increased serum prolactin level, and increased mortality rate from heart disease.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Critical factors for successful integration of loss during the grieving process are
a. the client's adequate perception, adequate support, and adequate</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>406</p>
<p>coping.</p>
<p>b. the nurse's trustworthiness and healthy attitudes about grief.
c. accurate assessment and intervention by the nurse or helping person.
d. the client's predictable and steady movement from one stage of the process to the next.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="multiple-response-questions">MULTIPLE RESPONSE QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#multiple-response-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Select all that apply.</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Rando's six Rs of grieving tasks include
a. react.
b. read.
c. readjust.
d. recover.
e. reinvest.
f. restitution.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nursing interventions that are helpful for the grieving client include
a. allowing denial when it is useful.
b. assuring the client that it will get better.
c. correcting faulty assumptions.
d. discouraging negative, pessimistic conversation.
e. providing attentive presence.
f. reviewing past coping behaviors.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-11">CHAPTER 11<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-11" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="anger-hostility-and-aggression">Anger, Hostility, and Aggression<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anger-hostility-and-aggression" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>anger
catharsis

<li>triggering phase</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="learning-objectives">LEARNING OBJECTIVES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>After reading this chapter, you should be able to:</p>
<ol>
<li>Discuss anger, hostility, and aggression.</li>
<li>Describe psychiatric disorders that may be associated with an increased risk of hostility and physical aggression in clients.</li>
<li>Describe the signs, symptoms, and behaviors associated with the five phases of aggression.</li>
<li>Discuss appropriate nursing interventions for the client during the five phases of aggression.</li>
<li>Describe important issues for nurses to be aware of when working with angry, hostile, or aggressive clients.</li>
</ol>
<p>409</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Anger, a normal human emotion, is a strong, uncomfortable, emotional response to a real or perceived provocation. Anger results when a person is frustrated, hurt, or afraid. Handled appropriately and expressed assertively, anger can be a positive force that helps a person resolve conflicts, solve problems, and make decisions. Anger energizes the body physically for self-defense when needed by activating the “fight-or-flight” response mechanisms of the sympathetic nervous system. When expressed inappropriately or suppressed, however, anger can cause physical or emotional problems or interfere with relationships.</p>
<p>Hostility, also called verbal aggression, is an emotion expressed through verbal abuse, lack of cooperation, violation of rules or norms, or threatening behavior (Schultz &amp; Videbeck, 2013). A person may express hostility when he or she feels threatened or powerless. Hostile behavior is intended to intimidate or cause emotional harm to another, and it can lead to physical aggression. Physical aggression is behavior in which a person attacks or injures another person or destroys property. Both verbal and physical aggression are meant to harm or punish another person or to force someone into compliance. Some clients with psychiatric disorders display hostile or physically aggressive behavior that represents a challenge to nurses and other staff members.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260121-4957caef.jpeg" alt="img-43.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hostility">Hostility<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hostility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Violence and abuse are discussed in Chapter 12, and self-directed aggression such as suicidal behavior is presented in Chapter 17. The focus of this chapter is the nurse's role in recognizing and managing hostile and aggressive behavior that clients direct toward others within psychiatric settings.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="onset-and-clinical-course">ONSET AND CLINICAL COURSE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#onset-and-clinical-course" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="anger">Anger<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anger" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>410</p>
<p>Although anger is normal, it is often perceived as a negative feeling. Many people are not comfortable expressing anger directly. Nevertheless, anger can be a normal and healthy reaction when situations or circumstances are unfair or unjust, personal rights are not respected, or realistic expectations are not met. If the person can express his or her anger assertively, problem-solving or conflict resolution is possible.</p>
<p>Anger or angry feelings are not bad or wrong. It isn't healthy to deny or try to eliminate ever feeling angry. It is essential for good health to recognize, express, and manage angry feelings in a positive manner. Anger becomes negative when the person denies it, suppresses it, or expresses it inappropriately. A person may deny or suppress (i.e., hold in) angry feelings if he or she is uncomfortable expressing anger. Possible consequences are physical problems such as migraine headaches, ulcers, or coronary artery disease, and emotional problems such as depression and low self-esteem.</p>
<p>Anger that is expressed inappropriately can lead to hostility and aggression. The nurse can help clients express anger appropriately by serving as a model and by role-playing assertive communication techniques. Assertive communication uses "I" statements that express feelings and are specific to the situation, for example, "I feel angry when you interrupt me," or "I am angry that you changed the work schedule without talking to me." Statements such as these allow appropriate expression of anger and can lead to productive problem-solving discussions and reduced anger.</p>
<p>Some people try to express their angry feelings by engaging in aggressive but safe activities such as hitting a punching bag or yelling. Such activities, called catharsis, are supposed to provide a release for anger. However, catharsis can increase rather than alleviate angry feelings. Therefore, cathartic activities may be contraindicated for angry clients. Activities that are not aggressive, such as walking or talking with another person, are more likely to be effective in decreasing anger. Cognitive behavioral therapy techniques, such as distraction, problem-solving, and changing one's perspective or reframing can be effective in managing situations or problems that provoke angry feelings (Horiuchi, Tsuda, Aoki, Yoneda, &amp; Sawaguchi, 2018).</p>
<p>High hostility and anger are associated with increased risk of coronary artery disease and hypertension. Hostility can lead to angry outbursts that are not effective for anger expression. Effective methods of anger expression, such as using assertive communication to express anger and mindfulness techniques, should replace angry aggressive outbursts of temper such as yelling or throwing things. Simply suppressing or attempting to ignore angry feelings may adversely affect control of hypertension (Crosswell et al., 2017).</p>
<p>411</p>
<p>Controlling one's temper or managing anger effectively should not be confused with suppressing angry feelings, which can lead to the problems described earlier. Anger-related personality traits and social inhibition are associated with the presence and severity of coronary artery disease (Lin et al., 2017).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260121-ca91583c.jpeg" alt="img-44.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="assertive-communication">Assertive communication<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assertive-communication" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Anger suppression is especially common in women, who have been socialized to maintain and enhance relationships with others and to avoid the expression of the so-called negative or unfeminine emotions such as anger. Women's anger often results when people deny them power or resources, treat them unjustly, or behave irresponsibly toward them. School-age girls report</p>
<p>412</p>
<p>experiences of disrespect, dismissal, and denial of the right to express anger. The offenders are not strangers, but are usually their closest intimates. Manifestations of anger suppression through somatic complaints and psychological problems are more common among women than men. Women must recognize that anger awareness and expression are necessary for their growth and development.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hostility-and-aggression">Hostility and Aggression<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hostility-and-aggression" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Hostile and aggressive behavior can be sudden and unexpected. Often, however, stages or phases can be identified in aggressive incidents: a triggering phase (incident or situation that initiates an aggressive response), an escalation phase, a crisis phase, a recovery phase, and a postcrisis phase. These phases and their signs, symptoms, and behaviors are discussed later in the chapter.</p>
<p>As a client’s behavior escalates toward the crisis phase, he or she loses the ability to perceive events accurately, solve problems, express feelings appropriately, or control his or her behavior; behavior escalation may lead to physical aggression. Therefore, interventions during the triggering and escalation phases are key to preventing physically aggressive behavior (discussion to follow).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="related-disorders">RELATED DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#related-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The media gives a great deal of attention to people with mental illness who commit aggressive acts. This gives the general public the mistaken idea that most people with mental illness are aggressive and should be feared. In reality, clients with psychiatric disorders are much more likely to hurt themselves than other people.</p>
<p>Although most clients with psychiatric disorders are not aggressive, clients with a variety of psychiatric diagnoses can exhibit angry, hostile, and aggressive behavior. Clients with paranoid delusions may believe others are out to get them; believing they are protecting themselves, they retaliate with hostility or aggression. Some clients have auditory hallucinations that command them to hurt others. Aggressive behavior is also seen in clients with dementia, delirium, head injuries, intoxication with alcohol or other drugs, and antisocial and borderline personality disorders. Violent patients tend to be more symptomatic, have poorer functioning, and show a marked lack of</p>
<p>413</p>
<p>insight compared with nonviolent patients (Zhu, Li, &amp; Wang, 2016).</p>
<p>Some clients with depression have anger attacks. These sudden intense spells of anger typically occur in situations in which the depressed person feels emotionally trapped. Anger attacks involve verbal expressions of anger or rage but no physical aggression. Clients describe these anger attacks as uncharacteristic behavior that is inappropriate for the situation and followed by remorse. The anger attacks seen in some depressed clients may be related to irritable mood, overreaction to minor annoyances, and decreased coping abilities.</p>
<p>Intermittent explosive disorder (IED) is a rare psychiatric diagnosis characterized by discrete episodes of aggressive impulses that result in serious assaults or destruction of property. The aggressive behavior the person displays is grossly disproportionate to any provocation or precipitating factor. This diagnosis is made only if the client has no other comorbid psychiatric disorders, as previously discussed. The person describes a period of tension or arousal that the aggressive outburst seems to relieve. Afterward, however, the person is remorseful and embarrassed, and there are no signs of aggressiveness between episodes (Ramesh, Hassamal, &amp; Moeller, 2017). IED develops between late adolescence and the third decade of life. Clients with IED are often men with dependent personality features who respond to feelings of uselessness or ineffectiveness with violent outbursts.</p>
<p><strong>Acting out</strong> is an immature defense mechanism by which the person deals with emotional conflicts or stressors through actions rather than through reflection or feelings. The person engages in acting-out behavior, such as verbal or physical aggression, to feel temporarily less helpless or powerless. Children and adolescents often "act out" when they cannot handle intense feelings or deal with emotional conflict verbally. To understand acting-out behaviors, it is important to consider the situation and the person's ability to deal with feelings and emotions.</p>
<p>There are numerous reports of violence toward both individuals and groups in the United States. The identified suspects or perpetrators are often described as having unresolved anger or a mental illness. It is important to remember that such reports may originate from family or neighbors and are their own personal perceptions of the situation. Sometimes, others may speculate about the causes of these violent actions. Just because an individual commits a seemingly incomprehensible act doesn't mean that person has a mental illness.</p>
<p>414</p>
<p>415</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="etiology">ETIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#etiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="neurobiologic-theories">Neurobiologic Theories<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neurobiologic-theories" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Researchers have examined the role of neurotransmitters in aggression in animals and humans, but have been unable to identify a single cause. Findings reveal that serotonin plays a major inhibitory role in aggressive behavior; therefore, low serotonin levels may lead to increased aggressive behavior. This finding may be related to the anger attacks seen in some clients with depression. In addition, increased activity of dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain is associated with increased impulsively violent behavior. Further, structural damage to the limbic system and the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain may alter the person's ability to modulate aggression; this can lead to aggressive behavior (Victoroff, 2017).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="psychosocial-theories">Psychosocial Theories<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#psychosocial-theories" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Infants and toddlers express themselves loudly and intensely, which is normal for these stages of growth and development. Temper tantrums are a common response from toddlers whose wishes are not granted. As a child matures, he or she is expected to develop impulse control (the ability to delay gratification) and socially appropriate behavior. Positive relationships with parents, teachers, and peers; success in school; and the ability to be responsible for oneself foster development of these qualities. Children in dysfunctional families with poor parenting, children who receive inconsistent responses to their behaviors, and children whose families are of lower socioeconomic status are at increased risk for failing to develop socially appropriate behavior. This lack of development can result in a person who is impulsive, easily frustrated, and prone to aggressive behavior.</p>
<p>The relationship between interpersonal rejection and aggression can also be the basis for long-term problems regulating and managing emotions, including anger as well as others. Rejection can lead to anger and aggression when that rejection causes the individual emotional pain or frustration, or is a threat to self-esteem. Aggressive behavior is seen as a means of reestablishing control, improving mood, or achieving retribution, all of which fail to achieve those ends (Victoroff, 2017).</p>
<p>CULTURAL CONSIDERATIONS</p>
<p>What a culture considers acceptable strongly influences the expression of anger. The nurse must be aware of cultural norms to provide culturally competent care. In the United States, women traditionally were not permitted to express anger openly and directly because doing so would not be "feminine" and would challenge male authority. That cultural norm has changed slowly during the past few decades. Some cultures, such as Native American and Asian cultures, see expressing anger as rude or disrespectful and avoid it at all costs. In these cultures, trying to help a client express anger verbally to an authority figure would be unacceptable.</p>
<p>Ethnic or minority status can play a role in the diagnosis and treatment of psychiatric illness. Patients with dark skin, regardless of race, are sometimes perceived as more dangerous than light-skinned patients, and therefore more likely to experience compulsory hospitalizations, increased use of restraints, higher doses of medication, and so forth. People of color are overrepresented in interpersonal violence episodes. However, when studies controlled for socioeconomic factors, race was not the significant factor; rather poverty, and other socioeconomic factors explained the difference (Victoroff, 2017). Education to develop cultural competence is needed to provide quality care to immigrants and minority group patients.</p>
<p>Hwa-Byung or hwabyeong is a culture-bound syndrome that literally translates as anger syndrome or fire illness, attributed to the suppression of anger (Lee et al., 2018). It is seen in Korea, predominately in women, and is characterized by sighing, abdominal pain, insomnia, irritability, anxiety, and depression. Western psychiatrists would be likely to diagnose it as depression or somatization disorder.</p>
<p>Two other culture-bound syndromes involve aggressive behavior. Bouffée délirante, a condition observed in West Africa and Haiti, is characterized by sudden outbursts of agitated and aggressive behavior, marked confusion, and psychomotor excitement. These episodes may include visual and auditory hallucinations and paranoid ideation that resemble brief psychotic episodes. Amok is a dissociative episode characterized by a period of brooding followed by an outburst of violent, aggressive, or homicidal behavior directed at other people and objects (Lewis-Fernandez, Kirmayer, Guarnaccia, &amp; Ruiz, 2017). This behavior is precipitated by a perceived slight or insult and is seen only in men. Originally reported in Malaysia, similar behavior patterns are seen in Laos, the Philippines, Papua New Guinea, Polynesia (cafard), Puerto Rico (mal de pelea), and among the Navajo (iich'aa).</p>
<p>416</p>
<p>417</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="treatment">TREATMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The treatment of aggressive clients often focuses on treating the underlying or comorbid psychiatric diagnosis such as schizophrenia or bipolar disorder. Successful treatment of comorbid disorders results in successful treatment of aggressive behavior. Lithium has been effective in treating aggressive clients with bipolar disorder, conduct disorders (in children), and intellectual disability. Carbamazepine (Tegretol) and valproate (Depakote) are used to treat aggression associated with dementia, psychosis, and personality disorders. Atypical antipsychotic agents such as clozapine (Clozaril), risperidone (Risperdal), and olanzapine (Zyprexa) have been effective in treating aggressive clients with dementia, brain injury, intellectual disability, and personality disorders. Benzodiazepines can reduce irritability and agitation in older adults with dementia, but they can result in the loss of social inhibition for other aggressive clients, thereby increasing rather than reducing their aggression.</p>
<p>Haloperidol (Haldol) and lorazepam (Ativan) are commonly used in combination to decrease agitation or aggression and psychotic symptoms. Patients who are agitated and aggressive but not psychotic benefit most from lorazepam, which can be given in 2-mg doses every 45 to 60 minutes. Atypical antipsychotics are more effective than conventional antipsychotics for aggressive, psychotic clients (Victoroff, 2017). Use of antipsychotic medications requires careful assessment for the development of extrapyramidal side effects, which can be quickly treated with benztropine (Cogentin). Chapter 2 provides a full discussion of these medications and their side effects.</p>
<p>Although not a treatment per se, the short-term use of seclusion or restraint may be required during the crisis phase of the aggression cycle to protect the client and others from injury. Many legal and ethical safeguards govern the use of seclusion and restraint (see Chapter 9).</p>
<hr>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-vignette-escalation-phase">CLINICAL VIGNETTE: Escalation Phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-vignette-escalation-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>John, 35 years of age, was admitted to the hospital for schizophrenia. John has a history of aggressive behavior, usually precipitated by voices telling him that he will be harmed by staff and must kill them to protect himself. John had not been taking his prescribed medication for 2 weeks before hospitalization. The nurse observes John pacing in the hall, muttering to himself and avoiding close contact with anyone else.</p>
<p>Suddenly, John begins to yell, “I can’t take it. I can’t stay here!” His</p>
<p>fists are clenched, and he is very agitated. The nurse approaches John, remaining 6 ft away from him, and says, "John, tell me what is happening." John runs to the end of the hall and will not talk to the nurse. The nurse asks John to take a PRN medication and go to his room. He refuses both. As he begins to pick up objects from a nearby table, the nurse summons other staff to assist.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nursing-care-plan-aggressive-behavior">NURSING CARE PLAN: AGGRESSIVE BEHAVIOR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-care-plan-aggressive-behavior" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nursing-diagnosis">Nursing Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Risk for Other-Directed Violence: Behaviors that an individual demonstrates indicating his or her potential to cause physical, emotional, and/or sexual harm to others</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="risk-factors">RISK FACTORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#risk-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Actual or potential physical acting out of violence</li>
<li>Destruction of property</li>
<li>Homicidal or suicidal ideation</li>
<li>Physical danger to self or others</li>
<li>History of assaultive behavior or arrests</li>
<li>Neurologic illness</li>
<li>Disordered thoughts</li>
<li>Agitation or restlessness</li>
<li>Lack of impulse control</li>
<li>Delusions, hallucinations, or other psychotic symptoms</li>
<li>Personality disorder or other psychiatric symptoms</li>
<li>Manic behavior</li>
<li>Conduct disorder</li>
<li>Posttraumatic stress disorder</li>
<li>Substance use</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="expected-outcomes">EXPECTED OUTCOMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#expected-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="immediate">Immediate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immediate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The client will</p>
<ul>
<li>Refrain from harming others or destroying property throughout hospitalization</li>
<li>Be free of self-inflicted harm throughout hospitalization</li>
<li>Demonstrate decreased acting-out behavior within 12 to 24 hours</li>
<li>Experience decreased restlessness or agitation within 24 to 48 hours</li>
<li>Experience decreased fear, anxiety, or hostility within 2 to 3 days</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stabilization">Stabilization<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stabilization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The client will</p>
<ul>
<li>Demonstrate the ability to exercise internal control over his or her behavior</li>
<li>Be free of psychotic behavior</li>
<li>Identify ways to deal with tension and aggressive feelings in a nondestructive manner</li>
<li>Express feelings of anxiety, fear, anger, or hostility verbally or in a nondestructive manner, for example, talk with staff about these feelings at least once per day by a specified date</li>
<li>Verbalize an understanding of aggressive behavior, associated disorder(s), and medications, if any</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="community">Community<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#community" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The client will</p>
<ul>
<li>Participate in therapy for underlying or associated psychiatric problems</li>
<li>Demonstrate internal control of behavior when confronted with stress</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="implementation">IMPLEMENTATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#implementation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Nursing Interventions</th><th>Rationale</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Build a trust relationship with this client as soon as possible, ideally well in advance of aggressive episodes.</td><td>Familiarity with and trust in the staff members can decrease the client’s fears and facilitate communication.</td></tr><tr><td>Be aware of factors that increase the likelihood of violent behavior or agitation. Use verbal communication or PRN medication to intervene before the client’s behavior reaches a destructive point and physical restraint becomes necessary.</td><td>A period of building tension often precedes acting out; however, a client who is intoxicated or psychotic may become violent without warning. Signs of increasing agitation include increased restlessness, motor activity (e.g., pacing), voice volume, verbal cues (I’m afraid of losing control.), threats, decreased frustration tolerance, and frowning or clenching fists.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th>If the client tells you (verbally or nonverbally) that he or she feels hostile or destructive, try to help the client express these feelings in nondestructive ways (e.g., use communication techniques or take the client to the gym for physical exercise).</th><th>The client can try out new behaviors with you in a nonthreatening environment and learn nondestructive ways to express feelings rather than acting out.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Anticipate the possible need for PRN medication and procedures for obtaining seclusion or restraint orders.</td><td>In an aggressive situation, you will need to make decisions and act quickly. If the client is severely agitated, medication may be necessary to decrease the agitation.</td></tr><tr><td>Develop and practice consistent techniques of restraint as part of nursing orientation and continuing education.*</td><td>Consistent techniques let each staff person know what is expected and will increase safety and effectiveness.</td></tr><tr><td>Develop instructions in safe techniques for carrying clients.*</td><td>Consistent techniques increase safety and effectiveness.</td></tr><tr><td>Be familiar with restraint, seclusion, and staff assistance procedures and legal requirements.</td><td>You must be prepared to act and direct other staff in the safe management of the client. You are legally accountable for your decisions and actions.</td></tr><tr><td>Always maintain control of yourself and the situation; remain calm. If you do not feel competent in dealing with a situation, obtain assistance as soon as possible.</td><td>Your behavior provides a role model for the client and communicates that you can and will provide control. Not all situations are within nursing’s expertise or control; recognizing the need for outside assistance in a timely manner is essential.</td></tr><tr><td>Calmly and respectfully assure the client that you (the staff) will provide control if he or she cannot control him or herself, but do not threaten the client.</td><td>The client may fear loss of control and may be afraid of what he or she may do if he or she begins to express anger or other feelings. Showing that you are in control without competing with the client can reassure the client without lowering his or her self-esteem.</td></tr><tr><td>Notify the charge nurse and supervisor as soon as possible in a (potentially) aggressive situation; tell them your assessment of the situation and the need for help, the client’s name, care plan, and orders for medication, seclusion, or restraint.*</td><td>You may need assistance from staff members who are unfamiliar with this client. They will be able to help more effectively and safely if they are aware of this information.</td></tr><tr><td>Follow the hospital staff assistance plan (e.g., use paging system to call for assistance to your location); then, if possible, have one staff</td><td>The need for help may be immediate in an emergency situation. Any information that can</td></tr></tbody></table>
