<p><strong>Additional Comments:</strong></p>
<p><em>Investigator’s Signature:</em></p>
<p>The Hamilton Rating Scale for Anxiety is in the public domain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history">History<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The client usually seeks treatment for panic disorder after he or she has experienced several panic attacks. The client may report, “I feel like I’m going crazy. I thought I was having a heart attack, but the doctor says it’s anxiety.” Usually, the client cannot identify any trigger for these events.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="general-appearance-and-motor-behavior">General Appearance and Motor Behavior<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-appearance-and-motor-behavior" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The nurse assesses the client’s general appearance and motor behavior. The client may appear entirely “normal” or may have signs of anxiety if he or she is apprehensive about having a panic attack in the next few moments. If the client is anxious, speech may increase in rate, pitch, and volume, and he or she may have difficulty sitting in a chair. Automatisms, which are automatic, unconscious mannerisms, may be apparent. Examples include tapping fingers, jingling keys, or twisting hair. Automatisms are geared toward anxiety relief and increase in frequency and intensity with the client’s anxiety level.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mood-and-affect">Mood and Affect<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mood-and-affect" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Assessment of mood and affect may reveal that the client is anxious, worried, tense, depressed, serious, or sad. When discussing the panic attacks, the client may be tearful. He or she may express anger at him or herself for being “unable to control myself.” Most clients are distressed about the intrusion of anxiety attacks in their lives. During a panic attack, the client may describe feelings of being disconnected from him or herself (depersonalization) or sensing that things are not real (derealization).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thought-processes-and-content">Thought Processes and Content<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thought-processes-and-content" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>During a panic attack, the client is overwhelmed, believing that he or she is dying, losing control, or “going insane.” The client may even consider suicide. Thoughts are disorganized, and the client loses the ability to think rationally. At other times, the client may be consumed with worry about</p>
<p>when the next panic attack will occur or how to deal with it.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sensorium-and-intellectual-processes">Sensorium and Intellectual Processes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sensorium-and-intellectual-processes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>During a panic attack, the client may become confused and disoriented. He or she cannot take in environmental cues and respond appropriately. These functions are restored to normal after the panic attack subsides.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="judgment-and-insight">Judgment and Insight<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#judgment-and-insight" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Judgment is suspended during panic attacks; in an effort to escape, the person can run out of a building and into the street in front of a speeding car before the ability to assess if safety has returned. Insight into panic disorder occurs only after the client has been educated about the disorder. Even then, clients initially believe they are helpless and have no control over their anxiety attacks.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="self-concept">Self-Concept<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#self-concept" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is important for the nurse to assess self-concept in clients with panic disorder. These clients often make self-blaming statements such as, "I can't believe I'm so weak and out of control" or "I used to be a happy, well-adjusted person." They may evaluate themselves negatively in all aspects of their lives. They may find themselves consumed with worry about impending attacks and may be unable to do many things they did before having panic attacks.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="roles-and-relationships">Roles and Relationships<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#roles-and-relationships" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Because of the intense anticipation of having another panic attack, the person may report alterations in his or her social, occupational, or family life. The person typically avoids people, places, and events associated with previous panic attacks. For example, the person may no longer ride the bus if he or she has had a panic attack on a bus. Although avoiding these objects does not stop the panic attacks, the person's sense of helplessness is so great that he or she may take even more restrictive measures to avoid them, such as quitting work and remaining at home.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physiological-and-self-care-concerns">Physiological and Self-Care Concerns<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physiological-and-self-care-concerns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The client often reports problems with sleeping and eating. The anxiety of apprehension between panic attacks may interfere with adequate, restful sleep, even though the person may spend hours in bed. Clients may</p>
<p>542</p>
<p>experience loss of appetite or eat constantly in an attempt to ease the anxiety.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="data-analysis">Data Analysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#data-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The following nursing diagnoses may apply to the client with panic disorder:</p>
<ul>
<li>Risk for injury</li>
<li>Anxiety</li>
<li>Situational low self-esteem (panic attacks)</li>
<li>Ineffective coping</li>
<li>Powerlessness</li>
<li>Ineffective role performance</li>
<li>Disturbed sleep pattern</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="outcome-identification">Outcome Identification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#outcome-identification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Outcomes for clients with panic disorders include:</p>
<ul>
<li>The client will be free from injury.</li>
<li>The client will verbalize feelings.</li>
<li>The client will demonstrate use of effective coping mechanisms.</li>
<li>The client will demonstrate effective use of methods to manage anxiety response.</li>
<li>The client will verbalize a sense of personal control.</li>
<li>The client will reestablish adequate nutritional intake.</li>
<li>The client will sleep at least 6 hours per night.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intervention">Intervention<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intervention" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="promoting-safety-and-comfort">Promoting Safety and Comfort<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#promoting-safety-and-comfort" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>During a panic attack, the nurse's first concern is to provide a safe environment and to ensure the client's privacy. If the environment is overstimulating, the client should move to a less stimulating place. A quiet place reduces anxiety and provides privacy for the client.</p>
<p>The nurse remains with the client to help calm him or her down and to assess client behaviors and concerns. After getting the client's attention, the nurse uses a soothing, calm voice and gives brief directions to assure the client that he or she is safe.</p>
<p>"John, look around. It's safe, and I'm here with you. Nothing is going to</p>
<p>543</p>
<p>happen. Take a deep breath."</p>
<p>Reassurances and a calm demeanor can help reduce anxiety. When the client feels out of control, the nurse can let the client know that the nurse is in control until the client regains self-control.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="using-therapeutic-communication">Using Therapeutic Communication<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#using-therapeutic-communication" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Clients with anxiety disorders can collaborate with the nurse in the assessment and planning of their care; thus, rapport between the nurse and the client is important. Communication should be simple and calm because the client with severe anxiety cannot pay attention to lengthy messages and may pace to release energy. The nurse can walk with the client who feels unable to sit and talk. The nurse should carefully evaluate the use of touch because clients with high anxiety may interpret touch by a stranger as a threat and pull away abruptly.</p>
<p>As the client's anxiety diminishes, cognition begins to return. When anxiety has subsided to a manageable level, the nurse uses open-ended communication techniques to discuss the experience:</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Nurse</strong>: “It seems your anxiety is subsiding. Is that correct?” or “Can you share with me what it was like a few minutes ago?”</p>
<p>At this point, the client can discuss his or her emotional responses to physiological processes and behaviors and can try to regain a sense of control.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="managing-anxiety">Managing Anxiety<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#managing-anxiety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The nurse can teach the client relaxation techniques to use when he or she is experiencing stress or anxiety. Deep breathing is simple; anyone can do it. Guided imagery and progressive relaxation are methods to relax taut muscles. Guided imagery involves imagining a safe, enjoyable place to relax. In progressive relaxation, the person progressively tightens, holds, and then relaxes muscle groups while letting tension flow from the body through rhythmic breathing. Cognitive restructuring techniques (discussed earlier in the text) may also help the client manage his or her anxiety response.</p>
<p>For any of these techniques, it is important for the client to learn and practice them when he or she is relatively calm. When adept at these techniques, the client is more likely to use them successfully during panic</p>
<p>544</p>
<p>attacks or periods of increased anxiety. Clients are likely to believe that self-control is returning when using these techniques helps them manage anxiety. When clients believe they can manage the panic attack, they spend less time worrying about and anticipating the next one, which reduces their overall anxiety level.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nursing-interventions">NURSING INTERVENTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-interventions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Provide a safe environment and ensure the client’s privacy during a panic attack.</li>
<li>Remain with the client during a panic attack.</li>
<li>Help the client focus on deep breathing.</li>
<li>Talk to the client in a calm, reassuring voice.</li>
<li>Teach the client to use relaxation techniques.</li>
<li>Help the client use cognitive restructuring techniques.</li>
<li>Engage the client to explore how to decrease stressors and anxiety-provoking situations.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="client-and-family-education">CLIENT AND FAMILY EDUCATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#client-and-family-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="for-panic-disorder">For Panic Disorder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#for-panic-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Review breathing control and relaxation techniques.</li>
<li>Discuss positive coping strategies.</li>
<li>Encourage regular exercise.</li>
<li>Emphasize the importance of maintaining prescribed medication regimen and regular follow-up.</li>
<li>Describe time management techniques such as creating “to do” lists with realistic estimated deadlines for each activity, crossing off completed items for a sense of accomplishment, and saying “no.”</li>
<li>Stress the importance of maintaining contact with community and participating in supportive organizations.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="providing-client-and-family-education">Providing Client and Family Education<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#providing-client-and-family-education" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Client and family education is of primary importance when working with clients who have anxiety disorders. The client learns ways to manage</p>
<p>545</p>
<p>stress and cope with reactions to stress and stress-provoking situations. With education about the efficacy of combined psychotherapy and medication and the effects of the prescribed medication, the client can become the chief treatment manager of anxiety disorder. It is important for the nurse to educate the client and family members about the physiology of anxiety and the merits of using combined psychotherapy and drug management. Such a combined treatment approach along with stress reduction techniques can help the client manage these drastic reactions and allow him or her to gain a sense of self-control. The nurse should help the client understand that these therapies and drugs do not "cure" the disorder but are methods to help him or her control and manage it. Client and family education regarding medications should include the recommended dosage and dosage regimen, expected effects, side effects and how to handle them, and substances that have a synergistic or antagonistic effect with the drug.</p>
<p>The nurse encourages the client to exercise regularly. Routine exercise helps metabolize adrenaline, reduces panic reactions, and increases production of endorphins; all these activities increase feelings of well-being.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="evaluation">Evaluation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#evaluation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Evaluation of the plan of care must be individualized. Ongoing assessment provides data to determine whether the client's outcomes were achieved. The client's perception of the success of treatment also plays a part in evaluation. Even if all outcomes are achieved, the nurse must ask whether the client is comfortable or satisfied with the quality of life.</p>
<p>Evaluation of the treatment of panic disorder is based on:</p>
<ul>
<li>Does the client understand the prescribed medication regimen, and is he or she committed to adhering to it?</li>
<li>Have the client's episodes of anxiety decreased in frequency or intensity?</li>
<li>Does the client understand various coping methods and when to use them?</li>
<li>Does the client believe his or her quality of life is satisfactory?</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="phobias">PHOBIAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phobias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A phobia is an illogical, intense, and persistent fear of a specific object or a</p>
<p>social situation that causes extreme distress and interferes with normal functioning. Phobias usually do not result from past negative experiences. In fact, the person may never have had contact with the object of the phobia. People with phobias have a reaction that is out of proportion to the situation or circumstance. Some individuals may even recognize that their fear is unusual and irrational but still feel powerless to stop it (Kimmel &amp; Roy-Byrne, 2017).</p>
<p>People with phobias develop anticipatory anxiety even when thinking about possibly encountering the dreaded phobic object or situation. They engage in avoidance behavior that often severely limits their lives. Such avoidance behavior usually does not relieve the anticipatory anxiety for long.</p>
<p>There are three categories of phobias:</p>
<ul>
<li>Agoraphobia (discussed earlier in text)</li>
<li>Specific phobia, which is an irrational fear of a particular object or a situation</li>
<li>Social anxiety or phobia, which is anxiety provoked by certain social or performance situations</li>
</ul>
<p>Many people express "phobias" about snakes, spiders, rats, or similar objects. These fears are specific, easy to avoid, and cause no anxiety or worry. The diagnosis of a phobic disorder is made only when the phobic behavior significantly interferes with the person's life by creating marked distress or difficulty in interpersonal or occupational functioning.</p>
<p>Specific phobias are subdivided into the following categories:</p>
<ul>
<li>Natural environmental phobias: fear of storms, water, heights, or other natural phenomena</li>
<li>Blood-injection phobias: fear of seeing one's own or others' blood, traumatic injury, or an invasive medical procedure such as an injection</li>
<li>Situational phobias: fear of being in a specific situation such as on a bridge or in a tunnel, elevator, small room, hospital, or airplane</li>
<li>Animal phobia: fear of animals or insects (usually a specific type; often, this fear develops in childhood and can continue through adulthood in both men and women; cats and dogs are the most common phobic objects)</li>
<li>Other types of specific phobias: for example, fear of getting lost while driving if not able to make all right (and no left) turns to get to one's destination.</li>
</ul>
<p>In social phobia, also known as social anxiety disorder, the person becomes severely anxious to the point of panic or incapacitation when confronting situations involving people. Examples include making a speech, attending a social engagement alone, interacting with the opposite sex or with strangers, and making complaints. The fear is rooted in low self-esteem and</p>
<p>547</p>
<p>concern about others' judgments. The person fears looking socially inept, appearing anxious, or doing something embarrassing such as burping or spilling food. Other social phobias include fear of eating in public, using public bathrooms, writing in public, or becoming the center of attention. A person may have one or several social phobias; the latter is known as generalized social phobia.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260121-d167ca77.jpeg" alt="img-54.jpeg"></p>
<p>Specific phobias</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="onset-and-clinical-course">Onset and Clinical Course<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#onset-and-clinical-course" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specific phobias usually occur in childhood or adolescence. In some cases,</p>
<p>548</p>
<p>merely thinking about or handling a plastic model of the dreaded object can create fear. Specific phobias that persist into adulthood are lifelong 80% of the time.</p>
<p>The peak age of onset for social phobia is middle adolescence; it sometimes emerges in a person who was shy as a child. The course of social phobia is often continuous, though the disorder may become less severe during adulthood. Severity of impairment fluctuates with life stress and demands.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="best-practice-psychosocial-interventions-versus-prn-medication">BEST PRACTICE: Psychosocial Interventions versus PRN Medication<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#best-practice-psychosocial-interventions-versus-prn-medication" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Best practices include implementation of nonpharmacologic interventions by staff prior to using PRN medications. They are safer, promote collaborative relationships, and teach skills needed to manage anxiety. Yet, use and documentation of psychosocial interventions is poorly documented.</p>
<p>The next step would be consistent implementation and documentation of psychosocial interventions to manage anxiety prior to the use of PRN medications.</p>
<p>Martin, K., Arora, V., Fischier, J., &amp; Tremblay, R. (2018). Analysis of nonpharmacological interventions attempted prior to pro re nata medications use. International Journal of Mental Health Nursing, 27(1), 296–302.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatment">Treatment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Behavioral therapy works well. Behavioral therapists initially focus on teaching what anxiety is, helping the client identify anxiety responses, teaching relaxation techniques, setting goals, discussing methods to achieve those goals, and helping the client visualize phobic situations. Therapies that help the client develop self-esteem and self-control are common and include positive reframing and assertiveness training (explained earlier).</p>
<p>One behavioral therapy often used to treat phobias is systematic (serial) desensitization, in which the therapist progressively exposes the client to the threatening object in a safe setting until the client’s anxiety decreases. During</p>
<p>549</p>
<p>each exposure, the complexity and intensity of exposure gradually increase, but the client's anxiety decreases. The reduced anxiety serves as a positive reinforcement until the anxiety is ultimately eliminated. For example, for the client who fears flying, the therapist would encourage the client to hold a small model airplane while talking about his or her experiences; later, the client would hold a larger model airplane and talk about flying. Even later, exposures might include walking past an airport, sitting in a parked airplane, and, finally, taking a short ride in a plane. Each session's challenge is based on the success achieved in previous sessions (Huppert &amp; Foa, 2017).</p>
<p>Flooding is a form of rapid desensitization in which a behavioral therapist confronts the client with the phobic object (either a picture or the actual object) until it no longer produces anxiety. Because the client's worst fear has been realized and the client did not die, there is little reason to fear the situation anymore. The goal is to rid the client of the phobia in one or two sessions. This method is highly anxiety producing and should be conducted only by a trained psychotherapist under controlled circumstances and with the client's consent.</p>
<p>Drugs used to treat phobias are listed in Table 14.3.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="generalized-anxiety-disorder">GENERALIZED ANXIETY DISORDER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#generalized-anxiety-disorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A person with GAD worries excessively and feels highly anxious at least 50% of the time for 6 months or more. Unable to control this focus on worry, the person has three or more of the following symptoms: uneasiness, irritability, muscle tension, fatigue, difficulty thinking, and sleep alterations. More people with this chronic disorder are seen by family physicians than by psychiatrists. The quality of life is diminished greatly in older adults with GAD. Buspirone (BuSpar) and SSRI or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor antidepressants are the most effective treatments (Ravindran &amp; Stein, 2017).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="self-awareness-issues">SELF-AWARENESS ISSUES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#self-awareness-issues" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Working with people who have anxiety disorders is a different kind of challenge for the nurse. These clients are usually average people in other respects who know that their symptoms are unusual but feel unable to stop them. They experience much frustration and feelings of helplessness and failure. Their lives are out of their control, and they live in fear of the next episode. They go to extreme measures to try to prevent episodes by avoiding</p>
<p>550</p>
<p>people and places where previous events occurred.</p>
<p>It may be difficult for nurses and others to understand why the person cannot simply stop being anxious and "calm down." Nurses must understand what and how anxiety behaviors work, not just for client care but to help understand the role anxiety plays in performing nursing responsibilities. Nurses are expected to function at a high level and to avoid allowing their own feelings and needs to hinder the care of their clients. But as emotional beings, nurses are just as vulnerable to stress and anxiety as others, and they have needs of their own.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="points-to-consider-when-working-with-clients-with-anxiety-and-anxiety-disorders">Points to Consider When Working with Clients with Anxiety and Anxiety Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#points-to-consider-when-working-with-clients-with-anxiety-and-anxiety-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Remember that everyone occasionally suffers from stress and anxiety that can interfere with daily life and work.</li>
<li>Avoid falling into the pitfall of trying to "fix" the client's problems.</li>
<li>Discuss any uncomfortable feelings with a more experienced nurse for suggestions on how to deal with your feelings toward these clients.</li>
<li>Remember to practice techniques to manage stress and anxiety in your own life.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="critical-thinking-questions">CRITICAL THINKING QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#critical-thinking-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Because all people occasionally have anxiety, it is important for nurses to be aware of their own coping mechanisms. Do a self-assessment: What causes you anxiety? What physical, emotional, and cognitive responses occur when you are anxious? What coping mechanisms do you use? Are they healthy?</li>
<li>Clients with anxiety disorders often engage in avoidance behaviors, hoping to escape environmental triggers and thereby avoid future anxiety attacks. How can the nurse ensure that these clients remain engaged in their daily lives? What interventions or teaching might be effective?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="key-points">KEY POINTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-points" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Anxiety is a vague feeling of dread or apprehension. It is a response to external or internal stimuli that can have behavioral, emotional, cognitive, and physical symptoms.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anxiety has positive and negative side effects. The positive effects produce growth and adaptive change. The negative effects produce poor self-esteem, fear, inhibition, and anxiety disorders (in addition to other disorders).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The four levels of anxiety are mild anxiety (helps people learn, grow, and change); moderate anxiety (increases focus on the alarm and learning is still possible); severe anxiety (greatly decreases cognitive function, increases preparation for physical responses, and increases space needs); and panic (fight, flight, or freeze response, no learning is possible, and the person is attempting to free him or herself from the discomfort of this high stage of anxiety).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Defense mechanisms are intrapsychic distortions that a person uses to feel more in control. It is believed that these defense mechanisms are overused when a person develops an anxiety disorder.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Current etiologic theories and studies of anxiety disorders have shown a familial incidence and have implicated the neurotransmitters GABA, norepinephrine, and serotonin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatment for anxiety disorders involves medication (anxiolytics, SSRI and tricyclic antidepressants, and clonidine and propranolol) and therapy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>CBTs used to treat clients with anxiety disorders include positive reframing, decatastrophizing, thought-stopping, and distraction.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In a panic attack, the person feels as if he or she is dying. Symptoms can include palpitations, sweating, tremors, shortness of breath, a sense of suffocation, chest pain, nausea, abdominal distress, dizziness, paresthesias, and vasomotor lability. The person has a fight, flight, or freeze response.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Phobias are excessive anxiety about being in public or open places (agoraphobia), a specific object, or social situations.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Self-awareness about one's anxiety and responses to it greatly improves both personal and professional relationships.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Unfolding Patient Stories: L.W. • Part 2</p>
<p>Recall from Chapter 9 L.W., a 48-year-old Native American diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer. The recommended treatment is a mastectomy followed by chemotherapy, which she refused. What is the association between her illness and episodes of severe anxiety since diagnosis? How can a secondary mental health disorder contribute to her physical decline from cancer? What psychosocial assessments and interventions should the nurse incorporate into the plan of care to manage her anxiety?</p>
<p>Care for L.W. and other patients in a realistic virtual environment: vSim for Nursing (<a href="http://thepoint.lww.com/vSimMentalHealth" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://thepoint.lww.com/vSimMentalHealth</a>). Practice documenting these patients' care in DocuCare (<a href="http://thepoint.lww.com/DocuCareEHR" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://thepoint.lww.com/DocuCareEHR</a>).</p>

<p>Kimmel, R. J., &amp; Roy-Byrne, P. (2017). Clinical features of the anxiety disorders. In B. J. Sadock, V. A. Sadock, &amp; P. Ruiz (Eds.), <em>Comprehensive textbook of psychiatry</em> (Vol. 1, 10th ed., pp. 1723–1730). Philadelphia, PA: Wolters Kluwer/Lippincott.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-readings">ADDITIONAL READINGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-readings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-study-guide">Chapter Study Guide<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-study-guide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="multiple-choice-questions">MULTIPLE CHOICE QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#multiple-choice-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<ol>
<li>The nurse observes a client who is becoming increasingly upset. He is rapidly pacing, hyperventilating, clenching his jaw, wringing his hands, and trembling. </ol>
<p>a. mild.
b. moderate.
c. severe.
d. panic.</p>
<ol start="2">

</ol>
<p>a. avoided until the anxiety is gone.
b. open-ended.

<ol start="3">

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="multiple-response-questions">MULTIPLE RESPONSE QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#multiple-response-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-example">CLINICAL EXAMPLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Martha Cummings contacted the Visiting Nurses Association (VNA) to discuss her concerns about her 29-year-old daughter Susan, who is a graphic designer. Martha explains that Susan has always been a shy person, has one or two close friends, and has difficulty dealing with new situations. Over the past 4 months, Martha reports Susan has been increasingly reluctant to leave her apartment, making excuses about not visiting her family and asking her mother to run errands and even purchase groceries for her. Martha also states that Susan has quit going to the office but has continued her job by working at home. Her employer has allowed her to do this for several weeks but is becoming more impatient with Susan. Martha fears Susan may lose her job.</p>
<p>When Martha attempts to talk to Susan about this situation, Susan becomes very anxious and agitated. She doesn't want to discuss her problems and keeps insisting she can't "go out there" anymore. Martha has not been able to convince Susan to see a doctor, so she contacted VNA to see if they would go to Susan's apartment to see her. Susan has agreed to talk to the nurse if the nurse comes to her apartment.</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>What assessments would the nurse need to make during the initial visit with Susan?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What type(s) of treatment are available for Susan?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>How is Martha’s behavior affecting Susan’s situation? What suggestions might the nurse make to Martha?</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>558</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-15">CHAPTER 15<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-15" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="obsessive-compulsive-and-related-disorders">Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#obsessive-compulsive-and-related-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="key-terms">KEY TERMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#key-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>compulsions
dermatillomania</li>
<li>excoriation
exposure</li>
